title: 111_hr5363
content: The Act may be cited as the "Preventing Waste, Fraud, and Abuse Act of 2010". The Congress finds that providing financial resources to Federal agencies is crucial to enforce laws and prevent waste, fraud, and abuse of taxpayer's dollars. Investing in program integrity efforts by the Department of Health and Human Services and the Department of Justice can result in significant savings, as reported by the Office of Management and Budget. Investing in program integrity efforts in Medicare, Medicaid, and the Children's Health Insurance Program could save $4.47 billion over 5 years and $9.87 billion over 10 years. Additionally, investing in Social Security Administration for disability reviews could save $10 for every $1 invested. Investing in program integrity efforts in the Social Security Administration for disability reviews could save approximately $8 for every $1 invested, according to the Office of Management and Budget. Additional funding for these reviews could result in an estimated savings of $16.1 billion. According to a report by the Office of Management and Budget, investing $3,953,000,000 could save $16,102,000,000 over 5 years, and investing $10,252,000,000 could save $57,838,000,000 over 10 years. The tax gap, the difference between taxes owed and paid, was estimated at $345,000,000,000 in 2005. In 2009, the Internal Revenue Service returned an average of $4 to the Treasury for every $1 invested in enforcing the tax code. Increasing tax enforcement efforts could save $13.87 billion on a $8.87 billion investment over 5 years and $62.22 billion on a $23.27 billion investment over 10 years. According to a report from the Office of Management and Budget, increasing in-person reemployment and eligibility assessments for the Department of Labor's unemployment insurance program could save approximately $3.19 billion over the next 10 years. This investment of $325 million over 5 years and $720 million over 10 years is estimated to save taxpayers nearly $2 billion. The report suggests that increasing in-person reemployment and eligibility assessments for the Department of Labor's unemployment insurance program could save taxpayers nearly $2 billion during fiscal year 2011, with potential savings of over $35 billion in the next 5 years and $132 billion in the next 10 years. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. Defines "agency head" as the heads of specific government departments and "Director" as the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. Each agency head, in consultation with the Director, must identify laws and regulations hindering the reduction of waste, fraud, and abuse of funds, and develop performance metrics to measure success in decreasing such issues. Each agency head must make accommodations for innovation and development to address program integrity efforts. Reports must be submitted to Congress within 6 months after the date specified. Congress must submit an interim report within 6 months of enactment, detailing performance metrics and how they will analyze program performance. A final report with developed metrics must be submitted within 1 year. Each agency head must publish these reports in the Federal Register and on their website. The agency must publish performance metrics in the Federal Register and on their website within 30 days of submitting the final report. Any modifications to the metrics must be reported to Congress within 30 days. The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) must submit an annual report to Congress using the developed metrics, starting the year after the final reports are due. The Director must submit an annual report to Congress measuring the agency's success in reducing waste, fraud, and abuse of funds. The report must include justifications for any modified performance metrics. Reports are referred to the Committees on Appropriations and Budget in both the House of Representatives and the Senate. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Department of Health and Human Services and the Department of Justice. The Department of Health and Human Services and the Department of Justice are authorized to receive increasing sums of money annually from 2011 to 2015 to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse in Medicare, Medicaid, and the Children's Health Insurance Program. The Social Security Administration is authorized to receive increasing sums of money annually from 2011 to 2013 for program integrity efforts, specifically for conducting disability reviews. The Department of the Treasury is authorized increasing sums of money annually from 2011 to 2020 for program integrity efforts, specifically for expanding tax enforcement activities. The Department of Labor is allocated increasing funds annually from 2012 to 2020 for program integrity efforts, including in-person assessments of unemployment insurance beneficiaries. The Department of Labor receives increasing funds annually from 2011 to 2016 for eligibility assessments of unemployment insurance beneficiaries, with a total of $395,000,000 allocated for fiscal years 2016 through 2020.
